item.title: Ticket #1012 (Rss2 feed) updated
item.dc:creator: yafd
item.description:
I'm having the same issue on all feeds (rss2, rss, atom, comments). I'm on IIS with NO permalink structure defined. $error never gets unset in wp-blog-header.php if empty($rewrite). The PATH_INFO condition above all that is true because my PATH_INFO is !empty (/wp-rss2.php). Could it be a paren out of place there? I patched mine by adding this at line 85 of wp-blog-header.php:

} else {

unset($error);

}

item.description: Missing closing bracket. Hat tip: Lucas.

item.title: Ticket #1025 (Update links doesn't check for failed socket open) updated
item.dc:creator: ColdForged
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #1025 (Update links doesn't check for failed socket open) created
item.dc:creator: ColdForged
item.description: The update links mechanism doesn't check for a failed socket open. On occasion, when a failure occurs, instead of failing gracefully the script caused a waterfall of errors to be logged -- mine was approximately 50M -- and if the cron job has an email listed it will fill the mailbox rapidly.

item.title: Ticket #1023 (get_links() ignores $echo setting) updated
item.dc:creator: MC_incubus
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #1023 (get_links() ignores $echo setting) created
item.dc:creator: MC_incubus
item.description: the get_links function's last parameter is $echo and is defaulted to true. Setting it to false does nothing, as the $echo variable isn't even looked at by the function.

item.title: Ticket #1019 (Moderation Queue listing doesn't include comment date) updated
item.dc:creator: coffee2code
item.description: Granted, it's not terribly important, but it's little overhead (just the addition of a line) and can help give some idea of the frequency in relation to time that comments are going into the moderation queue (especially since this is the sole view into the moderation queue, more especially if you have e-mail notifications disabled). Those 200 moderated comments may've come in over the course of a week, or the last hour.

item.description: When editing a draft, the "Existing timestamp" field always reflects the current time and not the time stored as the draft's post_date.

item.dc:creator: coffee2code
item.description: Patch changed

item.dc:creator: coffee2code
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #1021 ("Edit Time" and "Existing timestamp" fields always wrong when editing ...) created
item.dc:creator: coffee2code
item.description: When editing a comment (including a moderated comment), the comment form, under the "Advanced" section, always displays the current time for the "Edit time" input field and the "Existing timestamp" label. What it should display in both fields (at the very least the "Existing timestamp" field) is the date the comment was posted.

item.title: Ticket #1013 (Unable to use the comments popup script) updated
item.dc:creator: ryan
item.description: Codex is wrong. It defaults to an empty string which eventually results in a link of the form /?comments_popup=xx. Don't pass a file to comments_popup_script(), and it should work.

item.title: Ticket #1013 (Unable to use the comments popup script) updated
item.dc:creator: quidditch
item.description:
Do you mean :

comments_popup_script(600,600,'wp-content/themes/classic/comments-popup.php')

No because as explained in the codex :

​http://codex.wordpress.org/Template_Tags/comments_popup_script

the file string defaults to 'wp-comments-popup.php' which is nonexistent.

I guess the function has not been correctly ported to the new theme system.

item.title: Ticket #914 (wrong search string escaping/slashes) updated
item.dc:creator: nbachiyski
item.description:
I also prefer not adding slashes by default and escape strings only for DB operations.

Now, as I understand, the choice is between leaving the bug in 1.5.1 or applying the dirty "stripslashes in Kubrick" hack before reorganizing all that code. My choice was the second.

Which is the less evil of the two?

item.title: Ticket #914 (wrong search string escaping/slashes) updated
item.dc:creator: ryan
item.description:
Even if we get rid of the extra addslashes, searches will still show a single set of slashes. \' instead of
\'. We can either add stripslashes to Kubrick's templates, or not addslashes by default when processing GPC in the blog header. Not adding slashes by default and instead relying on those functions that query the DB to addslashes as appropriate seems to be the cleanest way to do this, but that should wait until after 1.5.1.

item.title: Ticket #1007 (do_action & arguments) updated
item.dc:creator: ryan
item.description:
To do call time pass by reference you have to use the array trick.

Example:

do_action('generate_rewrite_rules', array(&$this));

Patch changed

Install WP 1.5 on given platform, enter admin area, click on Plugins and try to activate any of the three available plugins.

item.title: Ticket #1015 (Cannot active Plugins) created
item.dc:creator: itst
item.description:
After successful installation on given platform, activiating plugins won't work.

When I try to activate any plugin by clicking on the activation link, PHP throws:

Warning: Invalid argument supplied for foreach() in C:\htdocs\wordpress\wp-settings.php on line 113

Warning: in_array() [function.in-array]: Wrong datatype for second argument in C:\htdocs\wordpress\wp-admin\plugins.php on line 9

Fatal error: [] operator not supported for strings in C:\htdocs\wordpress\wp-admin\plugins.php on line 10

item.title: Ticket #1014 (Category exclusion in wp_list_cats() returns error if excluded ...) updated
item.dc:creator: anonymousbugger
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #1014 (Category exclusion in wp_list_cats() returns error if excluded ...) created
item.dc:creator: anonymousbugger
item.description:
wp_list_cats('exclude=1,2,3,4,5,6,7');

returns an error if one of the categories is missing.

I also bumped into another problem, (i did not check if it was corrected): when you delete a category, wordpress puts whatever was in it into the default category. last time i checked, the default category remained the first one even if you changed it in the options. and the transfer query does not check if there are redundant items, e.g. you can have a post listed in a category twice, which wrecks the number of posts per category.

-- denis _\@/_ semiologic.com

item.title: Ticket #1004 (A less privileged user's post 'disappears' after they make an edit) updated
item.dc:creator: raena
item.description: I should add that it is unviewable in the *admin* area, not just on the site (I understand that having it 'disappear' from the site is normal), meaning that a higher privileged user cannot then pass it on for publishing.

item.title: Ticket #946 (comment moderation requests for entries with comments disabled) updated
item.dc:creator: anonymousbugger
item.description:
I ran into an issue today where a comment spam was put into moderation for a post that is in draft status. I have several posts in draft status, and although allow comments option is checked for this post, I don't believe that posts in draft status should accept comments. I've included a diff of a proposed solution, although maybe a specific action should be called so that if someone does want to allow comments on drafts, they could override it.

Index: wp-comments-post.php =================================================================== --- wp-comments-post.php (revision 2397) +++ wp-comments-post.php (working copy) @@ -3,12 +3,12 @@

$comment_post_ID = (int) $_POSTcomment_post_ID?;

-$post_status = $wpdb->get_var("SELECT comment_status FROM $wpdb->posts WHERE ID = '$comment_post_ID'"); +$post = $wpdb->get_row("SELECT post_status, comment_status FROM $wpdb->posts WHERE ID = '$comment_post_ID'"); -if ( empty($post_status) ) {

+if ( empty($post->comment_status)
( 'draft' == $post->post_status ) ) {

do_action('comment_id_not_found', $comment_post_ID); exit;

-} elseif ( 'closed' == $post_status ) { +} elseif ( 'closed' == $post->comment_status ) {

do_action('comment_closed', $comment_post_ID); die( ('Sorry, comments are closed for this item.') );

}

item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #1013 (Unable to use the comments popup script) created
item.dc:creator: quidditch
item.description:
I am trying to use the comments popup function. I had to add the following line in my header :

<?php comments_popup_script(600,600,'wp-content/themes/classic/comments-popup.php'); ?>

However, when I click on the popup link, I am greeted by a blank window with the following error message :

Fatal error: Call to undefined function: add_filter() in /mnt/myaccount/httpd/mylogin/mywebsite/html/testblog/wp-content/themes/classic/comments-popup.php on line 3

Line 3 being :

add_filter('comment_text', 'popuplinks');

item.title: Ticket #1011 (No option to clean comments flagged as spam) updated
item.dc:creator: jesuit
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #1011 (No option to clean comments flagged as spam) created
item.dc:creator: jesuit
item.description:
There is currently no easy way to delete the comments that 1.5 flags as spam. I checked my comments table recently and had 1500+ comments/trackbacks that were flagged as spam that I never saw, that is great until my table starts to become bloated.

There needs to be a mass delete option for those comments so the user can periodically clean out the chaff.
